div1.p: In this speech, to the Rotary Club of Havana, [Hench] mentions his marriage, his admiration of those involved in the yellow fever experiments, and some of the people he has met through his yellow fever research.

div1.head: Speech by [Philip Showalter Hench], January 1952

Dr Nogueira, Rotarians, Ladies and Gentlemen.

Mrs Hench and I are happy to be here today. My first visit to Havana was
in 1925 when I was a young unmarried man. Right away the spell of Cuba
must have affected me. At least it is a fact that I want straight from Havana
to Boston where a certain young lady was in college and asked her to marry
me. But she made me wait two years, perhaps because she had not yet
been touched by the magic of Havana. However shortly after we were
married I brought her here on a visit and we have lived happily ever since!

Every human heart needs inspiration, inspiration from the one on
High and inspiration from his fellow man. For years I have been
inspired by the wonderful story of the Conquest of Yellow Fever. For 15
years I have spent much of my leisure time visiting everyone still alive
who took part in this event.

Some of the richest experiences of my life have come from my
meetings and association with the relatives and close friends of
those who accomplished this magnificent achievement: your
illustrious countrymen Carlos Finlay and his devoted associate,
Claudio Delgado, and my own distinguished fellow countrymen
Major Walter Reed and his associates Drs Aristides Agramonte, Carroll
and Lazear.

I shall always remember with gratitude the wonderful hospitality
and friendliness which Mrs Hench and I have received from so
many here in Havana: among them Doctors Ramos and Albertini,
Andreu and Recio, and notthe least, my friend and gracious
host Dr Pedro Nogueira. Senoras Agramonte Rodriguez - Leon
and Rojas,

On this visit Mrs Hench and I miss so very much that
lovable Irish-American-Cuban, Johnny Moran, who lived his
life among you until he died here last year and who in 1900 at
the request of Major Reed and “for the sake of humanity” offered
his own living body to prove the bold theory of Carlos Finlay.

So profound are the secrets of nature, so complicated and
mysterious was the terrible problem of yellow fever that unfortunately,
no one man, however great he might be, could solve the mystery.
The conception of Carlos Finlay was one of the boldest, and most original
and most precise in the whole history of science. But before the world could
accept his ideas many others, to be exact over a score of others,
had to contribute their brains, their courage and, if need be, their lives.

Including first the inspired Dr Finlay these 25 men were
3 Cubans, 4 Spaniards, 1 Irishman, 1 Englishman and 16 Americans.
Some were Catholic, some were Protestant, some were Hebrews. United
in a common cause they comprised a unique “science-club,”
and one of history's finest examples of humanitarian cooperation.
That these men lived and worked here among your citizens
of Havana and Marianao must be a matter of tremendous
satisfaction.

To these men and to their Christian ideals of brotherly love
Mrs Hench and I pay our most humble tribute.
